conclusion: The problem involves predicting which container (D, E, or F) liquid will flow into after passing through baffles from starting points A, B, and C.
The diagram includes three starting points (A, B, and C) and three containers (D, E, and F). Colored lines represent flow paths, and baffles control the flow.
Point A has an orange line that flows downward and splits into two branches.
Point B has a purple line that flows downward and is deflected to the left by the purple slanted barrier.
Point C has a light blue line that flows downward and splits into two branches after straddling the brown slanted barrier.

premise: Stream A splits into two branches and merges with stream B. These merged streams encounter the blue and green slanted barriers and turn right along their respective baffles.
conclusion: The merged streams of A and B flow into container E.

premise: Stream C splits into two branches and drops directly without encountering additional obstacles.
conclusion: The two branches of stream C flow into containers E and F equally.

premise: No streams are directed toward container D.
conclusion: No liquid ends up in container D.

premise: The merged streams of A and B flow into container E, and the two branches of stream C flow into containers E and F equally.
conclusion: All mixture of A and B ends in container E; streams C separate into container E and F equally; no liquid ends in container D.
